dt: {bc}being, relating to, or characteristic of a {d_link|virtuoso|virtuoso}

dt.t: Generally speaking, the banjo and jazz parted ways many decades back, but {wi}virtuosic{/wi} banjoist Bela Fleck is almost single-handedly lobbying for reconciliation.
Yet it was from his craftsman father that he learned everything that there was to know about brick, and his use of that humble but infinitely versatile material was {wi}virtuosic{/wi}.

utxt.t: Later on, the voice became more assured, but it always remained no more than an impressive voice, expertly and {wi}virtuosically{/wi} executing its assigned role.
… a wonderful character dancer from the '70s, when American Ballet Theatre treasured comics, grumps, and eccentrics who could also dance {wi}virtuosically{/wi}.

shortdef: being, relating to, or characteristic of a virtuoso

dt: {bc}one who excels in the technique of an art

dt.t: Hailed far and wide as a {wi}virtuoso{/wi}, perhaps the greatest glass artist of the 20th century …

But the heart of the program was Beethoven, the Quartet in E Minor, Opus 59, No. 2, "Razoumovsky." This is where the modern string quartet begins, quartets that became the property of {wi}virtuosos{/wi} instead of amateurs …

dt: {bc}a person who has exceptional skill, expertise, or talent at some endeavor

dt.t: … instances in which young computer {wi}virtuosos{/wi} occasionally cross the legal boundaries of remote computer systems.
Although hockey has been more team-oriented than any other major sport, through the years there have been {wi}virtuosos{/wi} who packed the houses.

dt: {bc}a person interested in the pursuit of knowledge in some specialized field and especially in the arts and sciences

dt.t: [Samuel] Pepys was a characteristic product of his day, a {wi}virtuoso{/wi}, a man sympathetic to every new trend in science and scholarship.

dt: {bc}a person interested in or having a taste for the fine arts

dt.t: In the eighteenth century, rich "{wi}virtuosos{/wi}" like Richard Payne Knight and his friend Charles Townley assembled vast collections of everything from Roman sculpture to skewered beetles …

utxt.t: Canto LXXX … provides a particularly {wi}virtuoso{/wi} example of the poet's ear for dialects and languages.

et: Italian, from {it}virtuoso{/it}, adjective, virtuous, skilled, from Late Latin {it}virtuosus{/it} virtuous, from Latin {it}virtus{/it}
shortdef: one who excels in the technique of an art; especially : a highly skilled musical performer
a person who has exceptional skill, expertise, or talent at some endeavor
a person interested in the pursuit of knowledge in some specialized field and especially in the arts and sciences
